tax:div.tax:p: Description. FEMALE (n=10). Body vermiform,290 (215–293);74 (70–72) wide.Gnathosoma curved downwards,24 (21–29), dorsal pedipalpal genual setad5 (4–6), palpcoxal setaep2 (2), cheliceral stylets21 (21– 31).Prodorsal shield rhomboid-shaped,38 (35–40),47 (45–47) wide; ornamentation: with median line present on posterior1 /3, admedian lines present on posterior2 /3, first submedian lines present on posterior1 /3, parallel to lateral margin and curved towards centre forming lines above dorsal tubercles. Tubercles of setaesc on rear shield margin,19 (19–22) apart, setaesc27 (20–27).LegI35 (29–35); femur8 (8–9), genu6 (5–6), tibia7 (5–7); tarsus8 (5–8); solenidion tapered,20 (16–20); empodium6 (5–9), simple, bilaterally symmetrical, with5 (5) paired rays; femoral setaebv12 (12–14), genual setael′′32 (29–32), tibial setael′10 (8–10), tarsal setaeft′24 (20–24), setaeft′′28 (27–29), setaeu′6 (5–6).LegII39 (32–39); femur9 (9–10), genu5 (4–5), tibia4 (4–6); tarsus5 (5–8); solenidion tapered19 (16–19); empodium9 (6–9), simple, bilaterally symmetrical, with5 (5) paired rays; femoral setaebv15 (15–17), genual setael′′12 (12–14), tarsal setaeft′15 (12–15), setaeft′′30 (27–30), setaeu′7 (6–7).

Coxal plates with dashes; suboral plate with dots. Setaec236 (36–40), on3 rd (2 nd to4 th) annulus; setaed50 (42–56), on15 th (14 th to18 th) annulus; setaee23 (19–24), on26 th (26 th to34 th) annulus; setaef32 (24–34), on54 th (45 th to56 th) annulus,6 th (6 th) annulus from rear. Setaeh14 (4–5); setaeh243 (36–44).External genitalia20 (20–25),23 (23– 26) wide, genital coverflap with6 (6–8) striae; setae3a 20 (17–22),20 (18–21) apart.
Male, nymph and larva. Not found.
Type host plant.PlantaeMagnoliopsidaBoraginalesBoraginaceaeOnosmaisauricumspeciesBoiss. et Heldr.Onosma isauricum Boiss.et Heldr. (PlantaeMagnoliopsidaBoraginalesBoraginaceaefamilyBoraginaceae).
Relation to host plant. The mites were vagrant on leaves.
Type locality. Gevaş in Van,Turkey (38 °17 '52 "N,43 °06'16 "E),1040 m above sea level, coll. E. Denizhan,16 June2008.

Type material.Holotype female [3961 (1)] and6 femaleparatypes [3953–3958] deposited in the collection of the Faculty of Biology, Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznań,Poland and3 femaleparatypes [3963–3965] deposited in the collection of the Department of Applied Entomology, Faculty of Horticulture, Biotechnology and Landscape Architecture, Warsaw University of Life Sciences –SGGW, Warsaw,Poland.
Etymology. The specific mite name (adjective in the genitive case, feminine) is derived from the generic name of the host plant.

Differential diagnosis. The new species,AnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaonosmaespeciesA. onosmae, can be differentiated from other similar species such asAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaechiispeciesCanestrini, 1891Aceria echii (Canestrini,1891) onPlantaeMagnoliopsidaBoraginalesBoraginaceaeEchiumvulgarespeciesEchium vulgare L. (PlantaeMagnoliopsidaBoraginalesBoraginaceaefamilyBoraginaceae) inItaly andAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaeutrichaspeciesNalepa, 1894Aceria eutricha (Nalepa,1894) onPlantaeMagnoliopsidaBoraginalesBoraginaceaeLappulasquarrosaspecies(Ratz.) Dumort.Lappula squarrosa (Ratz.) Dumort. (PlantaeMagnoliopsidaBoraginalesBoraginaceaefamilyBoraginaceae) inAustria by having very long solenidia on both legs (ca.20). Also in contrast, the new species has pointed dorsal and ventral microtubercles. The prodorsal shield ornamentation ofAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaonosmaespeciesA. onosmae n. sp. shows that all lines are present on the rear part of the shield. InAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaechiispeciesA. echii andAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaeutrichaspeciesA. eutricha, the solenidia are at least twice shorter and there are less microtubercles on the annuli and these are smaller compared to the new species. InAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaechiispeciesA. echii, the ornamentation occurs on the whole shield in contrast to the new species. The prodorsal shield is smooth inAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaeutrichaspeciesA. eutricha. BothAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaechiispeciesA. echii andAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaeutrichaspeciesA. eutricha cause flower deformation and erinea whereasAnimaliaArachnidaProstigmataEriophyidaeAceriaonosmaespeciesA. onosmae sp. n. was observed to have a vagrant lifestyle.
